text: I can only SSH to my departament’s computer if I am inside my university’s VPN. University’s VPN doesn’t allow SSH’ing to the external supercomputer, so I cannot use two computers at a time.

elements.text: I can only SSH to my departament’s computer if I am inside my university’s VPN. University’s VPN doesn’t allow SSH’ing to the external supercomputer, so I cannot use two computers at a time.

text: You actually just run one instance of the ssh client behind a vpn and one not. for more details consult your OS specific information of choice
Wow, didn’t know this was possible/easy

elements.text: Wow, didn’t know this was possible/easy

text: Knowing that that is easy requires some understanding of OSI model. A good grasp of OSI is basically a super power when it comes to network related stuff. VPN is running a Layer 3 protocol (Hey please get this packet to ip"123.213.431.212") inside a Layer 5 (authenticated connection between two hosts anywhere in the network).
eeeh... that very much depends on how your OS chooses to expose this and how the VPN is implemented exactly.

elements.text: eeeh... that very much depends on how your OS chooses to expose this and how the VPN is implemented exactly.

text: in some configurations, it's not possible to split the tunnel, as it's called
